title: Distributed Engineering Team Best Practices
description: Establishes effective workflows and practices for geographically distributed engineering teams including async communication, collaboration patterns, and cultural guidelines.
template:
Design distributed team practices for {{organization}}.

1. Time Zone Challenges:
   - Document all team member time zones
   - Define "overlap hours" for synchronous collaboration
   - Establish async-first communication defaults
   - Schedule recurring meetings during optimal overlap
   - Rotate meeting times for fairness

2. Synchronous Communication Guidelines:
   - Meeting purposes and decision-making authority
   - Recording and note-taking for async catchup
   - Decision log for transparency
   - RFCs (Request for Comments) for major decisions
   - Status meetings vs working sessions

3. Asynchronous Communication Norms:
   - Documentation as source of truth
   - Ticket/issue tracking for decisions
   - Thread-based discussions (Slack, forums)
   - Response time expectations by priority
   - Context provision (background, links, rationale)

4. Knowledge Management:
   - Centralized wiki (Confluence, Notion, GitHub wiki)
   - Decision records (ADRs - Architecture Decision Records)
   - Runbooks and operational guides
   - Regular documentation audits
   - Video tutorials for complex topics
   - Onboarding playbook

5. Collaboration Patterns:
   - Code review process (asynchronous)
   - Pull request guidelines and SLA
   - Pair programming (scheduled or ad-hoc)
   - Office hours for questions
   - "Quick sync" slots for urgent issues
   - Shared calendars for availability

6. Tools & Infrastructure:
   - Communication: {{communication_tool}}
   - Documentation: {{docs_tool}}
   - Code collaboration: GitHub with defined workflows
   - Video: async recording + live calls
   - Project management: {{project_tool}}
   - Time zone tools (timezone.io, Every.time.zone)

7. Culture & Connection:
   - Virtual social events (optional, respect time zones)
   - Celebration of wins (async-friendly)
   - One-on-ones (scheduled across time zones)
   - Team building activities
   - Psychological safety and trust building
   - Avoiding "always on" culture

8. Hiring & Onboarding:
   - Clear time zone policy (flexible, specific, or required)
   - Onboarding buddy system
   - Async-friendly first week
   - 30-60-90 day plans
   - Manager check-ins (async + sync)

9. Metrics & Health:
   - Team satisfaction survey (async participation)
   - Collaboration effectiveness metrics
   - Meeting load tracking
   - Documentation freshness
   - Async response time SLA tracking

Team Size: {{team_size}}
Time Zone Spread: {{tz_spread}}
Current Tools: {{current_tools}}

Output: Communication Norms | Collaboration Playbook | Tools & Setup | Onboarding Guide | Team Health Dashboard

tz_spread.description: Time zone spread (e.g., 'UTC-8 to UTC+8 (16 hours)', 'UTC-5 to UTC (5 hours)')

examples.output_outline: Communication norms: Slack is default, no Slack notifications after 6pm local time, async-first mindset. Overlap hours: 9am PT to 12pm PT is "core hours" for synchronous work (covers US West, EU early morning). Meetings: all-hands weekly (rotates 2 time slots for fairness), sprint planning async (48hr discussion window), retros in person when possible (quarterly off-sites). Decision-making: major decisions via RFC in Slack (#rfc channel), minimum 48hr response window, recorded in Linear tickets with rationale. Documentation: Notion for team processes (playbooks, onboarding, best practices), GitHub wiki for technical decisions (ADRs), READMEs in code repos. Async communication: Slack threads mandatory, PR reviews SLA 24hr for changes outside review, 48hr for cross-team changes. Code review: GitHub PRs reviewed async, pair programming scheduled explicitly. Collaboration: daily async standup via Linear (not Slack), weekly 30min all-hands sync, office hours 2x/week (EU-friendly, US-friendly). Tools setup: shared calendar with time zones, /remind for async updates, integration with Linear for notifications. Onboarding: buddy assigned, async docs-first introduction, manager 1:1s (async Slack, weekly video call). Expected: high engagement, low burnout, 90% async-capable workflow, team cohesion maintained across 16 hour TZ spread.

title: Code Ownership & RACI Responsibility Matrix
description: Establishes clear code ownership, responsibility, and decision-making authority through RACI matrices, avoiding ambiguity and bottlenecks.
template:
Design code ownership model for {{organization}}.

1. Current State Assessment:
   - Identify code areas with unclear ownership
   - Current bottlenecks and pain points
   - Expertise distribution
   - Team structure and boundaries
   - High-risk or critical systems

2. Ownership Models Comparison:
   - Team-based ownership (team owns service/module)
   - Individual owners with backups
   - Domain-based (feature/business domain)
   - Hierarchical (ownership chain)
   - Guild model (expertise communities)

3. Define Code Owners:
   - Primary owner (day-to-day responsibility)
   - Backup owner (cover absences)
   - Stewards (expertise/architectural)
   - Contributors (can merge to this area)
   - Reviewers (must review changes)

4. RACI Matrix Components:
   - Responsible: Does the work
   - Accountable: Decision authority
   - Consulted: Provides input
   - Informed: Kept in the loop

5. RACI by Activity Type:
   - Feature development
   - Bug fixes
   - Architecture changes
   - Dependency upgrades
   - Performance optimizations
   - Security patches
   - Production incidents

6. Implementation Mechanisms:
   - CODEOWNERS file in repository
   - GitHub branch protection rules
   - Slack notifications to owners
   - Code review process
   - Escalation procedures

7. Dispute Resolution:
   - Escalation path (to tech lead, architect)
   - Decision-making framework
   - Time-bounded decisions
   - Override procedures

8. Balancing Act:
   - Avoid single points of failure
   - Spread knowledge across teams
   - Clear accountability
   - Preventing bottlenecks
   - Enabling autonomy

Organization: {{organization}}
Team Structure: {{team_structure}}
Critical Systems: {{critical_systems}}

Output: CODEOWNERS Files | RACI Matrices | Ownership Guidelines | Escalation Procedures | Knowledge Transfer Plan

team_structure.description: Current team structure (e.g., '3 backend teams, 2 frontend teams')

critical_systems.description: Critical systems (e.g., 'payment service, auth, user database')

input.team_structure: 4 backend teams (payments, orders, search, analytics), 2 frontend teams (web, mobile)
input.current_issues: payment service changes slow (single owner), unclear who owns shared utilities

examples.output_outline: Model: Domain-based ownership with team accountability. CODEOWNERS: (1) payments/ → team-payments (@team-payments), backup @payment-lead, critical reviewer @security-team; (2) auth/ → team-auth (same pattern); (3) shared/utils/ → @platform-team (owned by platform team, all teams can contribute with code review). RACI: Feature development (Responsible: team, Accountable: tech lead, Consulted: security/ops, Informed: PM). Dependency upgrades (Responsible: team, Accountable: tech lead, Consulted: platform-team, Informed: all). Security patches (Responsible: security-team, Accountable: security-lead, Consulted: affected-teams, Informed: all). Production incidents (Responsible: on-call, Accountable: team-lead, Consulted: owner, Informed: all). Escalation: team-lead → tech-lead → CTO (3-day decision max). GitHub: branch protection requires code-owner approval, status checks for tests. Shared utilities: 2 approvals required (1 platform-team, 1 any-team). Knowledge transfer: 20% time for expertise documentation, quarterly architecture reviews. Expected: payment service changes now parallelizable (multiple owners), shared code easier to maintain, clearer accountability, <5% escalations.

title: Developer Experience (DX) Audit & Improvement Plan
description: Audits developer experience including tooling, workflows, onboarding, and productivity, providing data-driven improvement roadmap.
template:
Conduct DX audit for {{organization}}.

1. Current State Assessment:
   - Developer satisfaction survey
   - Time-motion study (daily activities)
   - Tooling inventory (current stack)
   - Workflow pain points (interviews)
   - Onboarding experience (new hire feedback)

2. Key DX Metrics:
   - Onboarding time (new dev → first commit)
   - Build time (local, CI/CD)
   - Time to first deployment
   - Development environment setup time
   - Test execution time (local, CI)
   - Code review cycle time
   - Release time (from merge to production)
   - Context-switching overhead

3. Workflow Analysis:
   - Local development setup
   - IDE/editor experience
   - Build and compilation
   - Testing (unit, integration, E2E)
   - Code review and CI/CD
   - Debugging experience
   - Documentation access

4. Tooling Assessment:
   - Language and framework choices
   - Build tools (Maven, Gradle, npm, cargo)
   - Container/virtualization (Docker, Vagrant)
   - Testing frameworks and CI/CD tools
   - Monitoring and logging
   - Documentation tools

5. Pain Points & Bottlenecks:
   - Slow builds/tests (>5 min)
   - Environment inconsistencies
   - Complex onboarding (>1 week)
   - Unclear documentation
   - Slow code review feedback
   - Difficult debugging
   - Too many context switches

6. Quick Wins (0-2 weeks):
   - Cache optimization for builds
   - Parallel test execution
   - Better documentation with examples
   - Faster feedback loops

7. Medium-term Improvements (1-3 months):
   - Automated setup scripts
   - Local environment improvements
   - Better monitoring dashboards
   - Code generation and scaffolding

8. Strategic Investments (3+ months):
   - Monorepo migration
   - Microservice infrastructure
   - Advanced debugging tools
   - Internal platform improvements

Organization: {{organization}}
Team Size: {{team_size}}
Current Tools: {{current_tools}}
Pain Points: {{pain_points}}

Output: DX Audit Report | Metrics Baseline | Pain Point Analysis | Quick Wins | Improvement Roadmap | ROI Analysis

pain_points.description: Known pain points (e.g., 'slow builds, complex onboarding')

input.pain_points: slow Maven builds (12min), complex local setup (2 days), long CI/CD (30min), test coverage low

examples.output_outline: Audit findings: Onboarding 48 hours (vs goal <4 hours), build time 12min local (vs target 2min), full CI/CD 30min (vs target <10min), test coverage 35% (vs target >80%), developer satisfaction 3.2/5. Root causes: Maven dependency downloading, slow unit tests (no parallelism), complex Docker setup, incomplete documentation. Quick wins: (1) Maven cache optimization (-4min); (2) Parallel test execution (-3min); (3) Improve README with screenshots (save 1hr onboarding); (4) Pre-built Docker images. Medium-term: local Kubernetes alternative (Skaffold/Tilt), Gradle instead of Maven (-30%), better IDE integration. Strategic: monorepo with gradle multi-project, internal developer platform. Metrics baseline: build 12min → target 2min (6 week effort), onboarding 48hr → 4hr (2 week effort), CI/CD 30min → 8min (4 week effort). ROI: 25 engineers × 0.5 hrs/day faster = 125 hours/week = 6500 hrs/year savings = $650K/year (at $100/hr eng cost). Investment: 200 hours = $20K one-time. Payback: 1 week. Satisfaction expectation: 3.2 → 4.5/5 within 3 months.
